In an effort to perform proactive maintenance, over the next several days, Marietta Power will deploy a vehicle that will drive around our entire network scanning for overheating equipment.

The vehicle has a tracking infrared camera mounted to the top which will scan all overhead power lines looking for hot spots at all connection points. This will be done to proactively reduce our third leading cause of outages (equipment failure) by hopefully catching a large amount of equipment that is failing/overheating before its replacement lifecycle.

The Marietta Fire Department offers helpful firework safety tips as the July 4th holiday approaches.

According to the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, there are around 200 fireworks injuries every day during the month surrounding the Fourth of July. Each year in the U.S., around 11,000 people are treated in hospital emergency rooms for firework-related injuries. Follow these tips to help keep your family safe:

• Purchase fireworks from a licensed fireworks dealer.

• Observe all state laws regarding the use of fireworks.

• Read the labels carefully before igniting any fireworks.

• Ensure that an adult supervises all firework activities.

• Never allow children to ignite fireworks.

• Wear safety glasses when shooting fireworks.

• Light only one firework at a time.

• Only use fireworks outdoors in a clear area; away from buildings and vehicles.

• Never try to relight a firework.

• Have a garden hose or bucket of water nearby.

• Use caution with animals.

#ICYMI - Did you know that this week is National Community Development Week #CDWeek2020? We use this week, April 13-17th to celebrate the impact that the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program has made in communities across the country.

Since 2015, the City of Marietta has received over $2.5 million in CDBG funds from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. During this time, the City has completed numerous projects aimed at serving low-income families and communities which include:
-27 families received help through the Housing Rehabilitation Program
-$376,651 in grants were provided to local non-profits that provide services for low-income Marietta families
-$326,735 was spent on public works and facilities projects such as sidewalk improvements and park improvements in low-income neighborhoods

For more information, or to see if you qualify for assistance, visit https://www.mariettaga.gov/462/Community-Development

Today is an important day, today is Census Day. Filing out the 2020 Census is immensely important to our local community.

The results of the Census will also inform how hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funding are allocated to more than 100 programs, including Medicaid, Head Start, block grants for community mental health services, and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, also known as SNAP.

This means the Census directly affects funding for healthcare in our community and now more than ever we realize the importance of that fact. So please take a moment and fill out the Census online - https://my2020census.gov/. It is secure and confidential. Please do your part to help our community receive our share of federal funding.

The Marietta Museum of History is proud to present Made by Her Hands: The Beauty, Warmth and Stories of Local Quilting. This special exhibit highlights quilts made locally in Cobb County and the women who made them. Like the women who created them, these quilts provide warmth, comfort and leave hints to who they were. The quilt makers proudly left their marks on history in signatures and patterns. As pieces of art the quilts show individual creativity. Some even represent activism within the community as heirlooms auctioned off for charity.

Join us as we gaze upon the beautiful stitching, patterns and fabric choices, and imagine who made the quilts, why they were made and what these women’s lives were like.Try to imagine what impact they had on our history and what kind of stories we could tell if documented history had also been herstory.

The City of Marietta is pleased to announce that the city owned utility, Marietta Power, has received the Reliable Public Power Provider (RP3) award for 2020 from the American Public Power.

This is the third consecutive time Marietta Power has achieved the Diamond Level RP3 certification. The certification was first received in 2014 and Marietta Power once again received the designation in 2017.

The RP3 designation recognizes public power utilities that provide consumers with the highest degree of reliable and safe electric services. The designated utilities demonstrate proficiency in four key disciplines: reliability, safety, workforce development and system improvement. Criteria within each category are based on sound business practices and represent a utility-wide commitment to safe and reliable delivery of electricity.

Not only was Marietta Power the first Electric City in Georgia to earn RP3 designation in 2010, they earned it again in 2012 and Marietta Power was the first to earn Diamond status in Georgia in 2014.

post_text: The #MariettaFire Museum needs your help this Christmas season. Starting last year, the fire elves created a winter wonderland in the museum. A new addition this year is a train, but the village is a bit sparse. If you have any old snowy village pieces that are collecting dust at your house please bring them down to Station 51 located at 112 Haynes Street and our elves will add them to the decorations. Please drop them off Monday - Saturday between 9am and 3pm and bring the kids for a tour too!

Escape the crush of the mall crowds this shopping weekend. Come to the Marietta Square for Small Business Saturday®, where you’ll find what you’re looking for, and leave with memories you’ll want to re-live.

Shop Small Saturday is THIS Saturday - November 30th and the @mariettasquare has your Passport to Shop! Pick up your Shop Small Passport at any participating business, and for every purchase you make on November 30th, the participating business will stamp your passport with their custom stamp. (And have a little treat of some sort for you on the spot!) The Visit Marietta, GA (Welcome Center) will give you your first stamp without a purchase just for stopping by! If you get five stamps or more, drop your Passport in the Santa mailbox outside Church street Market or at the Marietta Welcome Center and you will be entered to win a very special drawing for a Marietta merchant gift basket full of prizes!

#mariettasquare
#shopsmallmariettasquare

post_text: Mayor Steve Thunder Tumlin will bestow all his Mayor's Awards to the Marietta City Schools kids on Monday, December 16 at 6:30pm at the Strand Marietta, but this one had to be given early for a very special reason. Ms. Raven Williams from the Marietta Center for Advanced Academics received the Mayor's award early because her mother, Staff Sergeant (SSG) Rhiannon Williams is serving her country and deployed right after Raven received her award. Congratulations to Raven and thank you to Staff Sergeant Williams for your service! Stay safe and we look forward to welcoming you home.
